contents.narration: The ghost can only be seen with your flashlight, so make sure to keep it on!

parameters.variableValue: The entity is in the room!

contents.narration: Snapping a photo of the ghost will reveal what type it is.  Try looking for better film while you are in the house.

parameters.variableValue: A spirit is a lost soul, not particularly dangerous and moderately prone to fleeing.
The gangly image of an emaciated young women floats before you.

You flip through a scrap book prepared delicately and elaborately by a Miss Yuki Mori. It depicts her senior year in high school before travelling to America to study abroad.  The final page is a photograph of her friends and family, waving farewell as she was entering the gate to board her flight to the United States.  Everyone is smiling, save for one dreary and exceedingly drab individual at the back of the crowd.

{'To your surprise, the batteries in a digital camera are sufficient to view the gallery.  The pictures depict a group of college students touring the western United States.  A series of photographs show an asian girl hysterically yelling at a slouching, verily depressed young man.  Then he was gone and the girl presumably fainted}

You find a single, water damaged polaroid.  It is a self-photograph of an asian girl in a bathtub.  She is obviously upset, tears pour from her eyes admist running mascara and saliva dripping from her mouth.  Sitting in the bathtub, behind her, is a young asian man with sallow, ashy skin.  You cannot see his eyes past his thick, wirey, black bangs.
The gluttonous bulk of an old man crawls from within the floor.

A black and white photograph shows the winners of a local youth bake-off.  First place went to a massive child, easily three times larger than the other children.  He is beaming with joy and satisfaction.

You find a desk plaque that reads 'An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.' Beneath you find a pocket ledger with diligent, consistent entries for a twelve year span that simply indicates the date and an gradually increasing measure of ounces.

The newspaper headline reads 'Mother Tortures Son to Lose Weight, Loses Her Life'.  The article depicts approximately 40 years of physical and mental abuse by Mrs. Agnus Hopper upon her son, Frank Hopper.  From the age of nine, she forced him to fillet parts of himself in order to lose weight.  Frank ended up filleting all of his mother's skin and muscle before doing the same to himself.
The darting blur of a young man catches your eye as it races from within the wall.
You find a child's pair of sneakers with silver lightning bolts hand painted on the sides.  The name 'Sam Yonk'is written in black marker on the sole of each shoe, barely visible from use.
There is a box filled with dusty trophies and medals.  The majority represent first place wins, with an occasional second here and there.  Each one was awarded to the same person, Tom Yonk.

You sit back and load up an 8mm home video found beneath a drawer with a false bottom.  It reveals two boys, one chained to a stone wall and one free and laughing wildly at the captive boy.  They are twins.  The free child is mocking chained boy with a medal while pelting him with pebbles.  Unnervingly, you presume the parents join in, laughing as the boy with the lightning bolt shoes hangs helpless and sobbing.
A shadow will do just that, stalk and follow you until one of you is gone.
The darkness of the house coaleses into the blurry, black figure and slowly moves towards you.
{'You find a participation medal from a 5K run.  An engraving on the back reads "Barry, How's the hip you sassy quickdraw?" Your Love Always, Rob."}

There is a copy of a police report here.  Apparently a Mr. Barry Crawford was severely beaten after leaving a New Year's Eve party.  The attached photos identify the location of multiple wounds, most startling is a crushed and mangled right hand; virtually pulverized.
You find a .38 revolver of stunning quality in a handmade oak box lined with velvet. A card inside reads 'Make them pay, I know you will not let me down.'
Your own shadow begins to shake and jitter as it animates and begins running its hands up your body.

There is a playbill here for the production of 'The Shaming of the True: A Modern Interpretation of an Old Story'.  It stars Miss Sally Hernandez; she adorns the cover in military fatigues, holding a voodoo doll in one hand, a headless unicorn in the other, and a wooden spatula between her teeth.

You find a crumpled up letter from the Academia de San Carlos in Mexico City. It summarizes that Miss Sally Hernandez was not accepted into the institute. The words "Beartrap Cougar" are scratched violently acrossed the page in red marker.

You flip through a file of notes and photographs.  The file was prepared by a private investigator and show the day to day trappings of a young women selling drugs and prostituting herself on the crowded Mexico City streets.
Tiny, dark images of people walking briskly begin to sprint and combine into a larger and larger figure that encompasses your field of view.
You find a set of souvenir spoons in a glass case.  Each spoon depicts one of the original United States colonies.  It appears that each one has been dipped in a red, waxy substance.

{'You come across a disiplinary notice for a high school student named Steven Wright.  It summarizes how the school supports Steven's interest in his ancenstral heritage but find the use of 'voodoo' and 'black magic' as distruptive to the school's educational goals and in some instances, biolgically hazardous to the health of the student body}

You humbly pick up what appears to be a grimoire; a magical tome.  Each page is thoughtfully and patiently scribed in indian ink; instructions for all manner of ritual, hex, incantation, and sorcery.  Much of the book is devoted to specific offerings and prayers to various Haitian Iwa and African Orishas.
Specters are terribly repulsed by light and will stop at nothing to flee from an altercation.
The shade of a distressed and frantic women erratically cuts through the air, its eyes black and sullen.

You open a small jewelry box containing a set of wings, some aviator sunglasses, and half of a cigar.  Below these momento is a photograph of a women, probably taken in the late 1960s.  She is standing next to a red, dual-prop aircraft, a lit cigar hanging from a tremendous smile.

You find a well-crafted, leather journal authored by Jane Blansky.  It is squarely focused on aircrafts and piloting, chronicling her journey to becoming a pilot, the troubles she faced as a women trying to make it as a pilot, and detailed logs of her flights.

You find a casette tape marked 'July 5, 1981, CVR'.  The final moments of the recorded flight involve a female pilot who is hijacked by three male stoaways.  The recording goes silent as you hear her fighting against the men entering the cockpit.
A young person hides in the corner crying and dissappears as you approach.
A hideous, pustule and sore-ridden monstrosity turns the corner and begins crawling towards you as it vomits a black, tar-like substance on the floor.
Apparitions are but echoes of their past lives, listlessly wondering forever in limbo.
The figure of a veiled women paces calmly before you.
{'You find a moldy, decaying diary.  Flipping through its musty pages unveils the day to day worries and hopelessness of a woman whose husband is dying."}
You find a Polaroid photograph taken in the 1980s.  It captures a dashing young man and a fetching young lady at an arcade, playing Pole Position.  They look quite happy.

Your rummaging uncovers a funeral order of service for a Mr. Robert Townsend, survived by Mrs. Tina Townsend.  They were married for 41 years.  The inky scratches of tears and mascarra have dried like scars throughout the program.
A middle-aged haze of a man manifests and repetatively bangs his head against the wall.

You discover a stack of telephone bills, neatly arranged in an accordian file.  Pulling up a sample reads like an international phonebook with calls to Japan, England, Brazil, Germany, Iceland; among others.  Page upon page of calls at all times of the day and night.
You happen upon a plaque and pen set presented to John Anderson for 57 years at ACME Commercial Real Estate.  The pen set and the placard appear to be made of gold.

You examine a photograph of a family at holiday party.  Three kids and their mother (you assume) sit on a couch next to an elaborately decroated fireplace.  Standing behind them you see a man, obviously upset, yelling into a telephone.
A young man, severed at the waist, continuously tries to lift himself up to walk and pitifully collapses.
You find a rusty, two-man crosscut saw.  It is still sturday despite its age.

You listen to a recorded message between two employees of the Buck Hanson Lumber Mill and another employee on the receiving end.  The two are heckling the newer and younger employee about an accident at the mill earlier that day.
You find a newspaper clipping; 'Employees's Jobs Cut Short After Harrasment Claim'.  'YUR NEXT' is scrawled in thick black marker over the newsprint.
The entity is in the room!

The totem generates its own piercing light.
You extend the totem in front of you and let its mystical energies shine.
The incantation is spoke with powerful words against those who wander.
You calmly recite the spell and feel the air around you become light and electric.

contents.narration: Here's the help menu. Choose the room you want to search by saying its name.  You can 'check' or 'examine' furniture for special items.  Keep your flashlight on by saying 'use flashlight'.  When you confront the ghost, first 'use camera' to get a clear picture and then 'attack' to try and banish it. Picking up where you left off.
